title.narrative: Improvement of livelihoods through honey bee farming

description.narrative:
This project will support 2,250 (500 families) extremely poor people, including adivasis (indigenous), landless and women headed households to undertake multi-cropping and inter-cropping, including the production of crops favourable to honey bees. The project will also train and provide inputs for 200 families to start beekeeping which will form part of wider Integrated Crop Management for improved crop yields. Ten bee-keeping groups will be formed, which will provide a platform for the participants to discuss learning, receive training and support each other. Small holder farmers groups will also be formed to train and disseminate techniques on multi-cropping and promote crops which benefit from bee pollination. 50 people will be supported as honey sellers and provide links between the producers and market.
The project will be implemented in Dinajpur in northern Bangladesh where the climate and topography is suitable for beekeeping for 9 months of the year. In this area, small and marginal farmers, particularly adivasi and women headed households suffer from food insecurity. Major reasons for this include low productivity of land, reliance on one rice crop, lack of capital and lack of knowledge on diversified cropping. Bees are of great economic importance as they not only produce honey and wax but act as primary pollinating agents for many crops varieties. This project will introduce this technology to exploit opportunities for honey production and improved crop yields for marginalised farmers. Beekeeping also plays an important role in sustainable agricultural development as it supports the environmental balance.
